DOC.HEAD: Rates Up in Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction to their highest level in three weeks. The Treasury Department sold $8 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.62 percent, up from 7.60 percent last week. Another $8 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.43 percent, up from 7.41 percent last week. The rates were the highest since Nov. 27 when three-month bills sold for 7.63 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.45 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.88 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,807.40 and 7.83 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,624.40. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, was 7.73 percent last week, the same as the previous week.
